channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: With Military Buildup Against Venezuela, the U.S. Eyes Cuba as Well
item.description: Washington hopes cutting off Venezuelan oil to Havana would collapse the Cuban regime.

item.title: Tanzania’s President Sworn In Amid Political Crisis
item.description: Samia Suluhu Hassan begins her second term after vote-rigging allegations and deadly protests rocked the country.

item.title: Why Is Trump Suddenly Talking About Invading Nigeria?
item.description: A U.S. military intervention would be a disaster in an already divided country.

item.title: The mystery of China’s slumping investment
item.description: Its leaders don’t seem too concerned. Should they be?

item.title: Will AI make dating apps better—or even worse?
item.description: Tinder, Hinge and Bumble are betting big on the technology

item.title: War is blasting Ukraine’s border city of Kharkiv but boosting Lviv
item.description: A tale of two Ukrainian cities

item.title: The U.N. Must Help Consolidate Gaza Peace
item.description: Trump should seek a Security Council resolution to bolster his peace plan and preempt spoilers.

item.title: The rise and fall of Stacey Abrams’s political machine
item.description: The New Georgia Project, her get-out-the-vote group, has folded

item.title: What the U.S. Supreme Court Tariffs Case Is Really About
item.description: The case is less about tariffs and more about whether the U.S. Constitution still matters.

item.title: The War Room newsletter: Did a Russian weapon spook Trump?
item.description: Shashank Joshi, our defence editor, talks missile protection—in Yorkshire

item.title: How a little Chinese island rose to global chemical dominance
item.description: A parable of China’s industrial supremacy

item.title: Argentina Is on a Path to Economic Success
item.description: While many commentators have criticized Argentine President Javier Milei's draconian approach to economic reform, the results of the October legislative election show that the Argentine people would prefer short-term economic pain over a return to Peronist policies. Milei now has a clear path to finish what he started.

item.title: ASEAN’s Moment of Truth
item.description: From the Asian financial crisis of the 1990s to the COVID-19 pandemic, the bloc has so far risen to the challenges it has faced. But it now confronts its biggest test yet: building balanced partnerships with powerhouses like China, India, Japan, and the US.

item.title: Introducing our free newsletter on health and wellness
item.description: Well Informed is your evidence-based guide to living your best life

item.title: What Is the Gold Price Telling Us?
item.description: With the price of gold hitting new records and pulling back sharply, is it a bubble or a sign of some profound, broader change in the global financial landscape? While the answer is anyone's guess, history does offer some clues.

item.title: Debt Relief as Currency Strategy: China’s Renminbi Push in Africa
item.description: In Kenya and Ethiopia, China is using debt distress as a strategic opening to expand the RMB’s international use.

item.title: Trump’s Violent New Monroe Doctrine
item.description: US airstrikes in the Caribbean reflect President Donald Trump’s view of intra-American relations as hierarchical. Whereas previous US presidents tried to reconcile Woodrow Wilson’s idealism with Theodore Roosevelt’s realism, Trump merges both impulses into a single, volatile creed: exceptionalism without responsibility or restraint.

item.title: Can the Gulf Rebuild the Middle East?
item.description: Despite many threats, the Gulf states have emerged with structural advantages that could reshape the region.

item.title: C5+1 at a Crossroads: Charting the Next Decade of US-Central Asia Engagement
item.description: As Washington contemplates the future of the C5+1, it must decide whether to adapt the mechanism to new geopolitical realities.

item.title: What COP30 Must Do
item.description: Whereas last year’s United Nations Climate Change Conference tripled the global climate-finance target, this year’s gathering must show how funds will be delivered. Developing countries are doing their part, but their climate strategies cannot succeed without external support.

item.title: Lee and Xi Agree to Strengthen China-South Korea Relations
item.description: Amid the aggravated rivalry between the two great powers, South Korea seeks to restore its bilateral relations with China.

item.title: In Kazakhstan, Energy Security Is Increasingly in Danger
item.description: While the war in Ukraine keeps evolving, recent counterattacks have put Kazakhstan’s energy system under growing threat.

item.title: How the Trump-Xi Meeting Was Read in Taiwan
item.description: Unusually, Taiwan didn't come up at the China-U.S. summit. But observers in Taiwan had plenty to say.

item.title: Is Bessent Right About the Fed?
item.description: The US Federal Reserve and most other G7 central banks have made numerous policy errors this century, making them ripe targets for criticism. But while reforms are necessary to improve their monetary-policy and regulatory performance, that does not mean their independence should be curtailed.

item.title: The Taliban’s Entry Into India-Pakistan Rivalry
item.description: Kabul’s flirt with New Delhi is a classic case of geopolitical logic.

item.title: India Is Disenfranchising Millions of Voters
item.description: A controversial policy may be targeting religious minorities and Dalits.

item.title: Taiwan’s Government Is Scared of Its Own Semiconductor Giant
item.description: Taipei needs to learn how to better wield the “silicon shield.”

item.title: Asia’s Dual Scramble: Critical Minerals, Energy, and the Traders Holding It Together
item.description: With global supply chains under unprecedented strain, traders have a critical role to play.

item.title: Why Russell Vought Is One of the Most Powerful People in Washington
item.description: Trump’s budget director is working through the system rather than around it.

item.title: The Quad Is Dead, Long Live the Quad
item.description: In an increasingly dangerous era, the group’s old patterns of cooperation will not suffice.

item.title: The Pacific Islands Challenge
item.description: In America’s tug of war with China, oceanic democracy is caught in the middle.

item.title: With Eye on Elections Bangladesh’s Jamaat-e-Islami Offers Vague Apology
item.description: The Islamist party had collaborated with Pakistan in genocide during the 1971 Liberation War. But its chief avoided mentioning its horrific role.

item.title: Why Indonesia’s Focus on Secondhand Military Purchases Could Backfire
item.description: While the approach offers a quick means of fulfilling the country's strategic needs, it could inflict significant costs over the longer term

item.title: Rebel Leader Reiterates Demand for Separate Flag and Constitution for Nagas in India’s Northeast
item.description: NSCN(IM) chief Thuingaleng Muivah returned home to Ukhrul in Manipur recently after six decades.

item.title: Singapore Police Seize $115M in Assets Tied to Cambodia’s Prince Group
item.description: The U.S. government has accused the conglomerate and its chairman, Chen Zhi, of running a network of forced-labor scam centers.

item.title: Is Donald Trump as unpopular as he seems?
item.description: The first big elections of his second term will provide some answers

item.title: Elections this week will show how unpopular Donald Trump really is
item.description: New York will make headlines. But keep an eye on New Jersey and Virginia, too

item.title: US, Vietnam Discuss Deeper Defense Cooperation, Possible Arms Sales
item.description: During meetings in Hanoi, visiting U.S. War Secretary Pete Hegseth said that closer military ties would "benefit both of our countries.”
